title: 107_hr3042
content: The "Neutral Cost Recovery Act of 2001" may be cited as the Act. It includes a depreciation adjustment for certain property placed in service after December 31, 2001. The "Neutral Cost Recovery Act of 2001" includes a deduction adjustment for tangible property placed in service after December 31, 2001, allowing for a 150 percent deduction instead of 200 percent under the accelerated cost recovery system. The Neutral Cost Recovery Act of 2001 allows for a deduction adjustment for tangible property placed in service, based on the applicable neutral cost recovery ratio for the taxable year. This ratio is determined by dividing the gross domestic product deflator for the calendar quarter ending in the taxable year. The Neutral Cost Recovery Act of 2001 allows for a deduction adjustment for tangible property placed in service, based on the gross domestic product deflator for the calendar quarter when the property was placed in service, multiplied by 1.035 to the power of the number of full years since the property was placed in service. The Neutral Cost Recovery Act of 2001 allows for a deduction adjustment for tangible property placed in service, based on the gross domestic product deflator for the calendar quarter when the property was placed in service. The applicable neutral cost recovery ratio shall never be less than 1 and shall be rounded to the nearest \1/1000\. Special rules apply for certain types of property. The gross domestic product deflator is used to adjust deductions for tangible property placed in service. Taxpayers can elect not to apply this adjustment, and certain transactions are exempt. The additional deduction does not affect the property's basis or recapture. Under this section, certain deductions shall not affect the adjusted basis of property or interests in pass-thru entities. A pass-thru entity is defined as a regulated investment company, real estate investment trust, S corporation, partnership, estate or trust, and common trust fund. Additionally, there are amendments to the minimum tax treatment under section 56(a) of the Code. The amendment to section 56(a) of the Code allows for the use of a neutral cost recovery ratio for property under section 168(k) placed in service after December 31, 2001. This ratio is applied to the deduction allowable for the property in each taxable year. The amendment allows for a neutral cost recovery deduction for property under section 168(k) and coordinates with the depreciation limitation on certain automobiles. The amendments made by this section allow for a neutral cost recovery deduction for property under section 168(k) and coordinate with the depreciation limitation on certain automobiles. These amendments apply to taxable years ending after December 31, 2001.
